newsitem.title: UK: Clarke says UK growth "balanced", not consumer-led.
newsitem.headline: Clarke says UK growth "balanced", not consumer-led.

text.p: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke said on Saturday that an "excellent week" of statistics had shown growth in Britain was balanced and not led by consumer demand.

Pointing to figures which showed March producer output prices up 1.0 percent year-on-year and retail sales growth "stabilising at less than three percent per annum", Clarke said: "That shows growth but balanced rather than consumer-led growth, with low prices for industry and business."

He told a news conference that borrowing figures released during the week showed Britain was well on course to balance the budget by the year 2000, while inflation data showed there was "low inflation being achieved during strong growth."

"When next month's figures are published we will know whether we attained our (core inflation) target of 2.5 percent...by the end of this parliament," he said. Core inflation was an annual 2.7 percent in March.
Clarke said the main opposition Labour Party, which is well ahead in opinion polls and widely expected to win the May 1 election, would jeopardise Britain's economy.
He said Labour would raise taxes and spending in a July budget if it won the election, and abandon the Conservative commitment to balance the budget by 2000.
